Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new environmental synthesis center that will stimulate research, education, and outreach at the interface of the natural and social sciences in order to develop novel and effective solutions to global environmental challenges. The center's founding plan requires mutual engagement of social and natural scientists in a facilitated process that leads to joint refinement of synthesis projects and the framing of questions that transcend disciplinary boundaries. This plan is grounded in four key goals: the creation of new coalitions; learning at all levels; expansion and improvement of the synthesis process; and creation of a flexible, adaptive institution. These goals will be achieved through community-driven activities that encourage diverse methods of collaboration including distributed interactions, the use of social media to consolidate collective knowledge from a broad constituency, data visualization, and design charrettes. Through engagement of multiple disciplines in innovative activities, the center promises a fundamental reorganization in how synthesis is accomplished and put into practice.

The Center will advance environmental synthesis science by combining diverse perspectives - those from basic research, public policy, science translation, and education. Policy scholars from Resources for the Future, along with policy makers, natural resource managers, and scientists from governmental agencies, will be integral to all center activities. The center presents an unprecedented opportunity to build capacity and broaden participation by advocating synthesis as a process that includes learning at all levels. Students will be trained in the skills needed to carry out synthesis and engaged directly in the synthesis process, with particular focus on hearing- and physically-impaired students, inner-city urban students, non-traditional students, and ethnic minorities. A key aspect of the center's vision is to advance the process of synthesis itself. Through continual evaluation and assessment of center activities and products, and adjustments to center philosophy and management in response to this evaluation, the center will function as a laboratory to facilitate learning about and improving the process of synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Socio-Environmental Synthesis Center (SESYNC) was established in 2011 through a cooperative agreement award from NSF to the University of Maryland. SESYNC's mission is to foster synthetic, actionable scholarship related to the structure, functioning, and sustainability of socio-environmental systems. To achieve this mission, SESYNC has five core objectives: 1) enhance the effectiveness of interdisciplinary collaborations among natural and social science research teams focused on environmental problems 2) build capacity and new communities of socio-environmental researchers 3) provide education programs to enhance interdisciplinarity and understanding of S-E synthesis 4) enhance computational capacity to promote socio-environmental synthesis; and 5) enhance relevance of socio-environmental research to decisions and behaviors via actionable scholarship.

These objectives have been met through a variety of research and training programs. In designing these programs, SESYNC leaders used an experimental organizational approach and a developmental evaluation approach to carefully design and implement core practices and processes. By treating the center as an 'experiment' and core practices as 'hypotheses,' SESYNC leaders have continuously adapted the center to better support research teams. A focus on tailoring support services - including computational support and consulting, facilitation services, iteration on research design, and consulting on team science challenges - to each unique team's needs has allowed SESYNC to simultaneously produce core research results while building capacity of researchers.

Over the course of this first cooperative agreement, SESYNC supported over 3,000 unique participants from a diverse range of disciplinary backgrounds, sectors, career stages, and geographical areas. Of SESYNC's core academic participants, around 43% were primarily natural scientists, 35% were primarily social scientists, and 22% had other expertise (including computer science, engineering, policy, humanities, and public health).

These participants came to the center as part of 90 synthesis teams (through programs called Pursuits, Ventures, and Foundations), 53 workshops, and 16 short courses. Additionally, we supported 36 in-residence postdoctoral fellows and hosted 14 sabbatical and short-term research fellows.

Collectively, these research projects produced over 400 publications. SESYNC peer-reviewed papers have been published in a highly diverse cross section of journals, including those with the highest impact factors such as Nature, Science, The Lancet, Trends in Ecology and Evolution, Ecology Letters, Nature Climate Change, and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. SESYNC researchers have also given over 600 presentations and talks and submitted at least 180 follow-on proposals for funding to expand upon research started at the center.

In addition to scholarly outcomes, SESYNC research has influenced decision makers and stakeholders across a variety of sectors. Researchers have given over 100 presentations to government agencies, international policymaking institutions, non-profits, and other organizations. Approximately 26% of SESYNC's core participants came from outside academia and SESYNC teams have included representatives from over 250 non-academic institutions, including for example at least 10 U.S. federal agencies, the World Bank, CGIAR, the International Food Policy Research Institute, The Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Institute.

Specific focal themes of SESYNC research have included:

  • Assessment & Modeling of Ecosystem Services
  • Data-Intensive Analysis and Modeling for Socio-Environmental Synthesis
  • Building Resources for Complex Action-Oriented Team Science
  • Water, People, & Ecosystems
  • Social & Environmental Dimensions of the Food-Energy-Water Nexus

In addition to support for research teams, SESYNC has offered a variety of formal training and professional development programs for graduate students, postdocs, and established scholars. For example, in addition to conducting original synthesis research, SESYNC resident postdoctoral fellows participated in our unique Socio-Environmental Immersion Program, a series of education and training activities intended to enhance interdisciplinarity and understanding of socio-environmental synthesis, identify and support new communities of socio-environmental researchers, and increase fellows' capacity for working in teams and conducting actionable science. SESYNC also developed a first-of-its-kind integrated training and research program for graduate students. The program included three workshops on socio-environmental synthesis, which presented doctoral students with training in team science, interdisciplinary collaboration, collaborative proposal writing and research design, and science communication.  These workshops served as the catalyst for three cycles of SESYNC's Graduate Pursuit Program, which resulted in 12 graduate-led synthesis teams conducting synthesis research as independent scholars in a highly interdisciplinary and real-life setting.

Other training and capacity-building opportunities provided by SESYNC included 16 short courses on computational skills and a series of undergraduate training programs for students underrepresented in the sciences that was implemented through partnerships with minority-serving institutions.

In 2018, SESYNC held an international symposium called "Boundary Spanning: Advances in Socio-Environmental Systems Research," which brought together participants from government, non-profit, and different stages of academic careers interested in innovating research and processes for solving socio-environmental problems.
